db_toolkit package¶

Submodules¶

db_toolkit.db_connection module¶

db_toolkit.db_connection.close_pool()¶

Close all connections in the global connection pool.

Return type:

None

db_toolkit.db_connection.create_connection_pool(host, port, dbname, user, password, minconn=1, maxconn=10)¶

Initialize a global PostgreSQL connection pool.

Parameters:

  • host (str) – The database host address.

  • port (int) – The port number to connect to.

  • dbname (str) – The name of the database.

  • user (str) – Username used to authenticate.

  • password (str) – Password used to authenticate.

  • minconn (int, default=1) – Minimum number of connections to maintain in the pool.

  • maxconn (int, default=10) – Maximum number of connections to maintain in the pool.

Returns:

Initializes the global connection pool for future use.

Return type:

None

db_toolkit.db_connection.get_connection(host=None, port=None, dbname=None, user=None, password=None)¶

Retrieve a PostgreSQL connection from the pool or create a direct connection.

If all parameters are provided, creates a direct connection. Otherwise, retrieves a connection from the global connection pool.

Parameters:

  • host (str, optional) – Database host address.

  • port (int, optional) – Port number to connect to.

  • dbname (str, optional) – Name of the database.

  • user (str, optional) – Username used to authenticate.

  • password (str, optional) – Password used to authenticate.

Returns:

A valid PostgreSQL connection object.

Return type:

psycopg2.extensions.connection

Raises:

Exception – If the connection pool is not initialized and parameters are not provided.

db_toolkit.db_connection.release_connection(conn)¶

Return a connection to the global pool.

Parameters:

conn (psycopg2.extensions.connection) – The PostgreSQL connection object to be returned.

Return type:

None

db_toolkit.ssh module¶

db_toolkit.ssh.create_ssh_tunnel(ssh_host, ssh_port, ssh_username, ssh_private_key, remote_bind_address, local_bind_address=('localhost', 0))¶

Create and start an SSH tunnel for secure remote database access.

Parameters:

  • ssh_host (str) – The hostname or IP address of the SSH server.

  • ssh_port (int) – The port on which the SSH server is listening.

  • ssh_username (str) – The username to authenticate with the SSH server.

  • ssh_private_key (str) – Path to the private key file for SSH authentication.

  • remote_bind_address (tuple of (str, int)) – The remote host and port to bind (e.g., database host and port).

  • local_bind_address (tuple of (str, int), optional) – The local address and port to bind. Default is (‘localhost’, 0), which means a random free port will be used on localhost.

Returns:

An active SSH tunnel object. Remember to call tunnel.stop() when done.

Return type:

sshtunnel.SSHTunnelForwarder

db_toolkit.sync_queries module¶

db_toolkit.sync_queries.run_query(host, port, dbname, user, password, query: str, params: tuple = None)¶

Execute a single SQL query (synchronously) and return the results as a DataFrame.

Parameters:

  • host (str) – Database host.

  • port (int) – Database port.

  • dbname (str) – Database name.

  • user (str) – Username for authentication.

  • password (str) – Password for authentication.

  • query (str) – The SQL query string. Can include %s placeholders.

  • params (tuple, optional) – Parameters to be passed safely to the query using placeholders.

Returns:

A DataFrame containing the result of the query.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

db_toolkit.threaded_queries module¶

db_toolkit.threaded_queries.run_parallel_queries(host, port, dbname, user, password, query_template: str, target_table, distinct_sources: dict, verbose: bool = True, debug: bool = False, max_combinations: int = None)¶

Run SQL queries in parallel using distinct combinations of values from multiple attributes, where each attribute may come from a different table.

Parameters:

  • host (str) – Database host.

  • port (int) – Database port.

  • dbname (str) – Database name.

  • user (str) – Username for authentication.

  • password (str) – Password for authentication.

  • query_template (str) – SQL query template with {table} and {attribute_0}, {attribute_1}, … placeholders. Must include %s for each attribute value in WHERE clause.

  • target_table (str or tuple) – Table (or schema, table) used in the query’s FROM clause.

  • distinct_sources (dict) – Mapping of attribute name to table (or schema, table) to use in the DISTINCT queries.

  • verbose (bool, optional) – If True, prints progress and active worker count. Default is True.

  • debug (bool, optional) – If True, prints debug information for each query and halts if an error occurs.

  • max_combinations (int, optional) – If provided, limits the number of combinations for debugging purposes.

Returns:

A DataFrame containing the concatenated results of all parallel queries.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

db_toolkit.utils module¶

db_toolkit.utils.get_env_variable(key, default=None)¶

Get the value of an environment variable.

Parameters:

  • key (str) – The name of the environment variable to retrieve.

  • default (str or None, optional) – A default value to return if the environment variable is not found.

Returns:

The value of the environment variable, or the default if not found.

Return type:

str or None

db_toolkit.utils.load_env(dotenv_path=None)¶

Load environment variables from a .env file.

If no path is provided, it defaults to loading a .env file located one level above the current module.

Parameters:

dotenv_path (str or None, optional) – Custom path to the .env file. If None, a default path is used.

db_toolkit.utils.log_query_failure(values, error_msg, log_file='query_failures.log')¶

Log the final failure of a query after all retries have been exhausted.

Parameters:

  • values (tuple) – The parameter values used in the failed query.

  • error_msg (str) – The error message received from the exception.

  • log_file (str, optional) – The file path to write the log to. Defaults to ‘query_failures.log’.

db_toolkit.utils.log_query_retry(values, attempt, error_msg, log_file='query_retries.log')¶

Log an intermediate retry attempt for a query that failed.

Parameters:

  • values (tuple) – The parameter values used in the query.

  • attempt (int) – The current retry attempt number.

  • error_msg (str) – The error message received from the exception.

  • log_file (str, optional) – The file path to write the log to. Defaults to ‘query_retries.log’.

db_toolkit.utils.require_env(keys)¶

Ensure that all required environment variables are set.

Parameters:

keys (list of str) – A list of environment variable names to validate.

Raises:

EnvironmentError – If one or more environment variables are not set.

db_toolkit.utils.safe_identifier(name)¶

Creates a psycopg2.sql.Identifier from a string or tuple (e.g., for schema.table).

Parameters:

name (str or tuple of str) – A single identifier (e.g., ‘table’) or a qualified identifier (e.g., (‘schema’, ‘table’)).

Returns:

A safely quoted SQL identifier.

Return type:

psycopg2.sql.Identifier

Module contents¶

db_toolkit¶

A lightweight and modular toolkit for secure and reusable database access via SSH tunnels, threaded and synchronous SQL queries, and environment management.

Modules¶

  • ssh : Create secure SSH tunnels using sshtunnel.

  • db_connection : Connect to PostgreSQL-compatible databases.

  • threaded_queries : Execute SQL queries in parallel by attribute.

  • sync_queries : Run single SQL queries synchronously.

  • utils : Load and validate environment variables from .env files.

db_toolkit.close_pool()¶

Close all connections in the global connection pool.

Return type:

None

db_toolkit.create_connection_pool(host, port, dbname, user, password, minconn=1, maxconn=10)¶

Initialize a global PostgreSQL connection pool.

Parameters:

  • host (str) – The database host address.

  • port (int) – The port number to connect to.

  • dbname (str) – The name of the database.

  • user (str) – Username used to authenticate.

  • password (str) – Password used to authenticate.

  • minconn (int, default=1) – Minimum number of connections to maintain in the pool.

  • maxconn (int, default=10) – Maximum number of connections to maintain in the pool.

Returns:

Initializes the global connection pool for future use.

Return type:

None

db_toolkit.create_ssh_tunnel(ssh_host, ssh_port, ssh_username, ssh_private_key, remote_bind_address, local_bind_address=('localhost', 0))¶

Create and start an SSH tunnel for secure remote database access.

Parameters:

  • ssh_host (str) – The hostname or IP address of the SSH server.

  • ssh_port (int) – The port on which the SSH server is listening.

  • ssh_username (str) – The username to authenticate with the SSH server.

  • ssh_private_key (str) – Path to the private key file for SSH authentication.

  • remote_bind_address (tuple of (str, int)) – The remote host and port to bind (e.g., database host and port).

  • local_bind_address (tuple of (str, int), optional) – The local address and port to bind. Default is (‘localhost’, 0), which means a random free port will be used on localhost.

Returns:

An active SSH tunnel object. Remember to call tunnel.stop() when done.

Return type:

sshtunnel.SSHTunnelForwarder

db_toolkit.get_connection(host=None, port=None, dbname=None, user=None, password=None)¶

Retrieve a PostgreSQL connection from the pool or create a direct connection.

If all parameters are provided, creates a direct connection. Otherwise, retrieves a connection from the global connection pool.

Parameters:

  • host (str, optional) – Database host address.

  • port (int, optional) – Port number to connect to.

  • dbname (str, optional) – Name of the database.

  • user (str, optional) – Username used to authenticate.

  • password (str, optional) – Password used to authenticate.

Returns:

A valid PostgreSQL connection object.

Return type:

psycopg2.extensions.connection

Raises:

db_toolkit.run_parallel_queries(host, port, dbname, user, password, query_template: str, target_table, distinct_sources: dict, verbose: bool = True, debug: bool = False, max_combinations: int = None)¶

Run SQL queries in parallel using distinct combinations of values from multiple attributes, where each attribute may come from a different table.

Parameters:

  • host (str) – Database host.

  • port (int) – Database port.

  • dbname (str) – Database name.

  • user (str) – Username for authentication.

  • password (str) – Password for authentication.

  • query_template (str) – SQL query template with {table} and {attribute_0}, {attribute_1}, … placeholders. Must include %s for each attribute value in WHERE clause.

  • target_table (str or tuple) – Table (or schema, table) used in the query’s FROM clause.

  • distinct_sources (dict) – Mapping of attribute name to table (or schema, table) to use in the DISTINCT queries.

  • verbose (bool, optional) – If True, prints progress and active worker count. Default is True.

  • debug (bool, optional) – If True, prints debug information for each query and halts if an error occurs.

  • max_combinations (int, optional) – If provided, limits the number of combinations for debugging purposes.

Returns:

A DataFrame containing the concatenated results of all parallel queries.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

db_toolkit.run_query(host, port, dbname, user, password, query: str, params: tuple = None)¶

Execute a single SQL query (synchronously) and return the results as a DataFrame.

Parameters:

  • host (str) – Database host.

  • port (int) – Database port.

  • dbname (str) – Database name.

  • user (str) – Username for authentication.

  • password (str) – Password for authentication.

  • query (str) – The SQL query string. Can include %s placeholders.

  • params (tuple, optional) – Parameters to be passed safely to the query using placeholders.

Returns:

A DataFrame containing the result of the query.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame
